headline: Papa Drexler's Bavarian Pretzels
description: Try this German pretzel recipe for homemade Bavarian pretzels that are soft, chewy, and golden brown with crispy specks of sea salt in every bite.
name: Papa Drexler's Bavarian Pretzels
recipeIngredient: 3 cups all-purpose flour, divided, or more as needed
1 tablespoon coarse sea salt, or to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Whisk 1 cup flour, yeast, and sugar together in a bowl. Stir in water and softened butter until well combined. Let stand until bubbles begin to form, about 15 minutes.
Stir salt into yeast mixture, then gradually stir in remaining 2 cups flour until dough can be picked up in a ball. Knead until smooth and elastic, about 8 minutes, adding more flour if needed.

Divide dough into 6 pieces and let rest for a few minutes. Roll one piece into a 15-inch rope, then loop and twist rope into a pretzel shape. Place onto a baking sheet and form remaining pretzels. Cover and let rise for 15 minutes.
Preheat the oven to 450 degrees F (220 degrees C). Grease a baking sheet.

Bring 3 cups water to a boil in a pot. Stir in baking soda and remove from the heat. Dip pretzels into the water bath for about 45 seconds, flipping over about halfway through. Transfer soaked pretzels to the prepared baking sheet; brush with melted butter and sprinkle with salt.
Bake in the preheated oven until golden brown, 8 to 10 minutes.

review.reviewBody: This recipe is wonderful and so easy to follow and then you eat a pretzel that tastes like you got them from a bakery in Bavaria I would recommend this recipe to all. Delicious.
Fun and crunchy. Real Philly taste!

Without the proper flour, it's impossible to make authentic bavarian pretzels. That said, these are very good! I made both pretzel twists and buns to accompany weisswurst. Tip: to stretch the dough, gently pull from both ends while tapping the center on the bread board. Twist the length of dough before shaping the pretzel for a pretty stripe effect.

I've used other recipes to make homemade pretzels and loved them, but these were "Bavarian" so I thought I'd give them a shot.

Very disappointed. They don't have the classic pretzel flavor or consistency. My whole family reacted, basically, with "I guess they're OK." I'll go back to my other recipes....
these pretzels are so easy to make they are quite large though. my family and I love them
I let the dough rise for an hour after the initial mix and I used a lye bath. Fantastic!

A tip for those that have trouble with the water bath. After shaped, let them rise on counter about 20 minutes, place in the refrigerator uncovered and allow them to form a skin for about 45 minutes and have your water bath ready. To get a better pretzel flavor try baking your baking soda on a foil lined sheet in the oven at 300F for 1 hour; this will make it more alkaline and more like the traditional lye that is used and not as caustic. I prep a whole tray of baking soda and store in the pantry for pretzels and bagels. I use about 1/3 cup per 6 cups water.

I have made this recipe several times now and even though I do not get a crispy result they are still really tasty and everyone loves them. They are always best the first day but if you put them in the toaster oven to freshen them up a day later, they are still pretty yummy!!
Delicious and very easy to make.
Yummy

Ok y’all....PLEASE weigh your ingredients! I only added about an extra half cup of flour. And do a second rise! After you knead it...cover and let rise until double. (About an hour ish). Then proceed. Those that said they ended up with pretzel disks...that’s what happens! That yeast is WORKING! I made 8 and they’re tasty!

I love the results. I have been looking for a recipe for a while and this is it. It is simple and produces great results. I made pretzels successfully but also used it for pretzel buns. Great results either way.

These pretzels are delicious! Just the right mix of salty, soft goodness! It’s a perfect snow day activity. The only thing I would do differently, is make smaller pretzels. They are so good that once you start eating, even if you’re full, you can’t stop!

I loved it! Simple and delicious. We had to use restraint not to finish them all in 10 minutes!
I split the dough into balls after kneading and let rise for 40 minutes before rollungout and shaping

this was my second attempt ever making pretzels. this recipe was easy to follow. I did add extra flour, but attributed it the humidity in the kitchen. 
I worked the dough by hand, which resulted in the fluffy texture others have described. the two of us ate 3 1/2 pretzels straight away with a beer cheese. 
there were no issues with them sticking to the cookie sheet.
I did over butter the tops, however, we like the buttery flavor. 
can't wait to make these for guests.
Came out great

These are absolutely amazing! I followed the directions exactly. I didn’t have any coarse salt in the house but would’ve used it. These will definitely be a staple in the house now. Thank you for sharing your recipe.

Love these. I am not a huge fan of American pretzels, so decided I just have to try and make my own more German style ones, and gave this recipe a try. And it’s superb. I didn’t change a thing in the ingredients. Kneeded the dough by hand for around 8 mins. With the baking soda bath, I boiled the water and added the soda, I then poured it into a shallow bowl, just enough to fully submerge the prezel. I dunked them only a few seconds at a time. That way no flipping needed. 
Baked them for around 12 minutes, lovely crisp to the crust and soft centre.
Was great.
Makes a great roll for a breakfast sandwich or burger.
These were great! Only problem is they didn't darken quite as much as I'd like, but that could just be my oven. I cooked them for 18 minutes. Next time I'll try making 8 smaller ones.

Had to add more flour, like 3/4 cup more.
I loved the outside shell and the inside dough was soft and tasted like bread. 
I was expecting more of a dense pretzel like dough inside. To me it just tasted like bread. I would make them again but seems like they needed more of a sourdough feeling to the dough and to be tougher. My daughter made a couple of much smaller ones which actually seemed closer to real pretzels then the large ones I made. Yes, I did knead the dough for at least 8 minutes. I made these for a party and everyone enjoyed them, so they were good. 
I am not much of a baker, so not sure what I would change next time.
good

These are good, nice and soft and not too complicated tp make. Not quite what I get at the local pub, but a decent sub when I can't go out (and cheaper)! I let them reat about 15 min after splitting the dough and before shaping. This was probably too long as they nearly fell apart in the water - they probably need to remain a bit denser. I will make them again with this small adjustment.

I’ve made this recipe 4 times since finding it. WIN! Another reviewers input on hand vs machine mixing was very useful! In the end, I prefer the machine mixing. I’ve used the recipe to make regular pretzels, pretzel balls, pretzel wrapped sausages, and more. Works and tastes great!
Great taste and cooked all the way through with a nice color on top.. I had to add a lot more flour to get a good consistency and a little more butter.
I made a half batch & made 6 pretzels. I think next time I will make them even smaller because I love the crispy outside - DELISH! I may even try using 1/2 whole wheat flour for a hearty flavor.
Great recipe! Loved the crunch! Easy to make. Thank you for the fine recipe!
Amazingly easy to make and sooooo delicious!!!
I made the recipe exactly as written. My only regret is that I didn't double the ingredients to make more. My family LOVED them!
My son loves pretzels and we've been looking for a good recipe. "Found it!" Love the recipe.

These were totally fab! My German husband also gave these his seal of approval. I was always curious about why a pretzel skin has that sharp, clear, almost bitter taste and now I know. This will definitely be a regular snack in our household!
We left the sausage whole and had it for dinner instaed of an appetizer. We really liked it. Made for a different use of out homemade smoked bratwurst. Will definitely make this again.
Will not make again.recipe lacked flavor.

I had to cook them longer than the 10 minutes to get them not so doughy. They actually tasted pretty good, just unappealing.
Kids really enjoyed these. Fairly simple to make.
Pretty yummy!
Better than the last recipe I used. I’m from Philly and we love our soft pretzels, and I can tell you these pretzels was delicious and not too hard to make! Enjoy

This was my first pretzel recipe I ever tried (I am very much a novice when it comes to baking anything involving yeast), and I'm pleased to say that even I couldn't ruin these. I followed the recipe with one small adjustment: I read in another comment that reducing the water bath from 3 cups to 2.5 strengthens the effect of the baking soda, so I followed that advice. I will say that the dough was VERY sticky, and while I was kneading I was having some trouble keeping everything together. I ended up adding quite a bit of flour (gradually, during kneading), and thankfully it all turned out fine. 

My only real advice is to Google how to twist a pretzel before you go about making these. You might think "who doesn't know how to twist a pretzel?" but I promise you, if your only preparation for twisting a pretzel is that you've *seen pretzels before,* you're gonna have a hard time. 

Oh, and double the recipe, because everyone is going to want seconds.
Loved them
FANTASTIC!! This has become a family tradition. Thank you for sharing the recipe. We love these pretzels.
I had been craving a soft pretzel for a few days so decided to make my own. really glad I chose this recipe. they turned out wonderfully and a fairly simple to make
It will take about 4cups of flour to be workable. Stretch to longer than the 15 inches, more like 18-20 inches. You will get no more than 4 on a large baking sheet if divided into 6 portions.
So tasty!
So tasty!
They were delicious. I would separate the dough into smaller sections. They cook faster and more people can enjoy them.
Great recipe. Make them every Easter.
Dough too sticky with proportions recommended ended up making buns instead
I found them too thick, but I knew that when I wasn’t rolling them out. ANd they weren’t really brown and crusty on the outside. I’ll try them again. Any suggestions?

I thought they would be darker and left them in for about 15 minutes, total.

perfect every time. I used an egg glaze instead of butter.

Perfect!

Only change I would make is that after the 10 minutes in the oven I would flip them and cook for another 2 minutes just to crisp the bottom a touch. Other than that a fantastic recipe!

These turned out excellent. I made sticks because they are easier to eat and I am too lazy to make traditional shape! I was seriously concerned with the soaking phase because they puffed up and became very friable. I ended up baking mine for about 13 minutes. Now to make some beer cheese!
Great recipe. Worked well the first time, and will likely improve with practice.
Amazing, delicious and easy. Needed a lot of flour during the kneading. Baked 10 minutes and could have had a minute or two more.
Delicious, wish I had made some cheese sauce to go with. The perfect amount of crunch.
These were simple to make and taste great! add at least 1/2 cup flour when kneading.
It was amazing but better eat it while it's fresh!
THe second time I made theses brezen (pretzels) I did NOT brush them with butter before baking, the result was a more authentic crisper outside. Will definitely made again.

I’m a fairly experienced baker, and these did not work out at all, as instructed. Too much yeast or rising time, these fell apart in boiling process and become soggy and wet when baked. This recipe could probably be redeemed, but followed as is, was a huge fail.

I made four batches. One with 100% Whole Wheat Flour and no butter (I forgot), one with Whole Wheat Flour and Vital Wheat Gluten, and two with Unbleached White Flour and butter.
 The whole wheat flour pretzels were okay, but they needed more salt... and butter to dip them in.
 I much preferred the Unbleached White Flour version. They were pillow soft, chewy, and really good.
Making it again this week. Philly people are pretzel people and this recipe is awesome
Needed a lot more flour, wouldn't brown so cooked for 14-15 min, stuck to the pan terribly. With all these great reviews we must've done something wrong
Amazing! These were super delicious and extremely fun to make!!!
Recipe was perfect from the start I have made this recipe over a dozen times and I loveit

I thought these were great and will definitely make them again. I probably added another half-cup of flour while kneading the dough, and next time I will probably add a little more butter on top for extra flavor. Overall, these turned out well and were fairly easy to make.

More flour needed. To prevent soggy-ness, took out of water placed on cookie sheet prepped with no stick spray. Let drip off a bit, then moved to sprayed baking sheet. Egg wash. Took a bit longer in oven than recipe...quite tasty!

These are wonderful and deserve 10 stars for ease of making and end product! I made the recipe as stated (at little hesitant due to the lack of rising time) and it works! Couple of notes: 1) I used to Kitchen Aid to knead the entire time and used at least 3/4 cup more flour; 2) note the 1 Tbsp of yeast! This is more than 1 small packet but less than 2; and 3) my baking time was closer to 16-18 min. Thanks so much Papa D!!! 

ps. Mustard/cheese sauce is great compliment.
.

Followed the recipe without any changes. These were AWESOME! When it comes to shaping the pretzel, I saw a video that suggested rolling the dough into a log shape that's shorter than what you need, waiting a couple of minutes for the gluten to relax, and then rolling out to the right length & twisting into the shape. This made it a lot easier!

This recipe tasted good, but did not brown like they are pictured. Mine looked more yellow and only got crispy in spots. Actually I baked them two different ways- done in the oven and some in an electronic pretzel press. The ones in the press actually were crispier. The outside did not come out with a smooth outside. Real-deal German pretzels have an outer crust that almost looks like skin- very smooth with s split along the bottom. The European style pretzels are tough to make. our kind of flour is so different.

I've made 16 pretzels using white wheat flour. I used the soda bath right after I removed the pot from the stove. That was a mistake. 
Allow the soda bath to cool off a bit. This allows the pretzels to maintain their shape, avoid the soda taste, and get crispy.

These were good in that any homemade bread is good. I'm making and comparing a few soft pretzel recipes in preparation for an Oktoberfest party, so I suggest1 - Use bread flour, not AP flour. The dough was really soft and sticky, I had to knead in some more flour just to handle it, and the first few I rolled did not develop good surface tension and absorbed water during the alkaline bath. Once I got the right amount of flour incorporated, they rolled better. I find that recipes made with AP flour tend to have this issue where ones made with bread flour don't. 2 - Use a full teaspoon of salt. The dough was a bit bland, and more salt would have helped.

Ultimately the texture of these is like a soft mall pretzel -- delicious in their own right. -- not so much a crusty pub pretzel which is what I'm after. 

Finally, I used a trick for the alkaline bath where I baked 1c of baking soda for 2 hours at 250 to dehydrate it and raise the Ph, which gives better browning. Then I used 3T of this baking soda with the water, and dipped each pretzel for 30 seconds on each side. This yielded the best pretzel crust I've made to date!
I made these for my husband one day and they lasted about 20 mins. After that he had me make them everyday for a month.
I made these for my husband one day and they lasted about 20 mins. After that he had me make them everyday for a month.

Absolutely perfect if you follow the recipe! It made more than 6! I made a cheese dip with it- mix melted butter, cheddar cheese, Monterey Jack cheese and a little beer on the stove until all melted and blended. Heavenly!
Delicious. 10/10 when fresh out of the oven. 7/10 if you have to reheat them. Best when hot and fresh, for sure.

This recipe makes an authentic German pretzel! If you divide the dough into four pieces, you will get pretzels that are the right size for a German bakery pretzels. I have made these twice and they came out great both times. An egg wash is visually appealing and I prefer it to brushing them with butter.

It's an all around decent recipe, but I would suggest either omitting the yeast altogether or letting the dough proof for 30 minutes before shaping. doesn't taste very "pretzely" but still delicious with cheese for dipping.

I have made this a couple of times, and I quite enjoy the taste of a yummy homemade pretzel. I like to make mine to use as a pretzel bun for sandwiches. It also good dipped in beer and cheese dip. My only issue is that the cooking instructions seem off, and I haven't been able to master how long to cook them for.
I was a bit disappointed with the result.
Made these for our beer tasting party. I should have doubled the recipe they loved them so much!

I made these a couple of weeks ago. Dough was a little sticky right out of the bowl. I just used a little extra flour at a time as I kneaded the dough. They were easy and delicious. Everyone loved them. I could have baked a little longer for a crustier top. But over all a BIG HIT.
swelled well and was good with chocolate sauce.
I will keep this recipe, it was a huge hit! Everyone really liked them.

Made a double batch (using each batch to make 8 instead of 6) for a small party of 4 people. They were all eaten by the end of the evening. Everyone loved them! I will make these again, and I am posting a link to this recipe on my blog for others to find as well :)
I can't believe I actually made pretzels! These are awesome and my wife loved them!

These were so much fun to make and they turned out awesome. Definitely will make them again and again. I was looking for something to make for my "pub fare" party and these will definitely be on the menu. When I make them for pub fare I will make them smaller so that they won't fill my guests up to quickly. Made the way the recipe calls for they are impressive and beg to be made into gourmet sandwiches.
Made a huge big batch for a social event. After rolling the first 30 into pretzels, I made the next 30 into pretzel buns which was way easier. Delicious!!!
Made a huge big batch for a social event. After rolling the first 30 into pretzels, I made the next 30 into pretzel buns which was way easier. Delicious!!!

first time I've made pretzels, so was just doing what it said and hoping it was sensible. These turned out great, although the fatter ones needed an extra minute to brown. Very easy with great result, although they stuck to the tray and I think they could have used another minute.
I made no changes, these were amazing!

Quick and easy, loved it.
I made a second batch with pumpkin seeds, ground flax seeds and chia seeds mixed into the dough to boost the nutritional value. Turned out great.
Thanks Papa D.

Wonderful and not too hard to make. Even fun for the kids to roll out the dough and shape the pretzels. Made these about 10 times so far since they are SO good.
I found if I do not added butter on top they get more of a golden brown, or maybe just be sure to add a little butter not too much. Just experiment with one or two with the butter since it could depend on your oven. Also I made a water/baking soda bath so you don't need to flip the pretzels, and a spatula to scoop them out.
If you do not dip them in the water/baking soda bath, you can make them dessert pretzels by adding sugar and cinnamon on top.
Do use a flat baking sheet without ridges as these things tend to stick.
Okay, I totally was planning on taking a picture but we ate the pretzels before I could snap a pic. They were fabulous and fun to make with the whole family! Enjoy a pretzel and a beer or glass of
